question_text: [conﬁrming] Yeah. Are you now in a space as you called former friend, friends, associates, last night to apologise, are you in a space where you’re not just apologising but you can begin to feel how you shattered other people’s lives? Are you in that space yet?
answer_text: Yeah, yeah. Yeah. And we don’t need the… I don’t need to be back in that place where I can slip like that and take things for granted and abuse privilege.

question_text: We all know that when you’re famous people love to see the rise, the heroic rise, and they also love to see you stumble and fall. Will you rise again?
answer_text: I don’t know, I don’t know. I don’t know what’s out there. And again I go to this thing, I do not know the outcome here, and I’m getting comfortable with that.

question_text: More importantly than your “come back”, I’m not as interested in your comeback to the sports world, I more interested what’s going to happen to you as a man, as a man, as a human being. Are you a better human being today because this happened. Did this help you become a better human being?
answer_text: Without a doubt, without a doubt. And again, this happened twice in my life, when I was diagnosed I was a better human being after that and I was a smarted human being after that. And then I lost my way.

question_text: It’s an epic story. What’s the moral to the story?
answer_text: It’s… I don’t have a great answer there. I can look at what I did, cheating to win bike races, lying about it, bullying people, of course you’re not supposed to do those things – that’s what we teach our children. That’s the easy thing.
